results.title: Crossing borders
results.creator_credit: Jeanne Kracher, Barbara Laing, Linda Balek and Film Project for Women's History and Future
results.brief_description: The story of the Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom, the longest standing organisation of its kind. Begun during the first World War and still alive all around the world, the WILPF is a testament to women’s historic resistance to militarism and oppression. Despite their important place in history, the WILPF’s study has, until now, remained buried. “Crossing Borders” uncovers this dramatic and forgotten chapter in history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeanne Kracher, Barbara Laing, Linda Balek and Film Project for Women’s History and Future

results.title: Crosses
results.brief_description: A documentary that examines the experiences of Australian soldiers fighting in the Middle East and at Gallipoli during World War 1, between 1914-1918. Archival film footage shows the conditions on the battlefields, and ex-soldiers recount their experiences.
results.description: A documentary that examines the experiences of Australian soldiers fighting in the Middle East and at Gallipoli during World War 1, between 1914-1918. Archival film footage shows the conditions on the battlefields, and ex-soldiers recount their experiences.

results.title: Creating a homely atmosphere
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit
results.brief_description: Designed to introduce the intellectual disability residential care worker to some simple ways of creating a homelike environment in the physical sense with furnishing and decor, how to create a desirable psychological atmosphere through community involvement and high quality staff-resident, staff-staff and resident-resident interactions, an interpretation of the term “normalisation” and how this principle might be applied in a residential setting and the recognition of the individual resident’s rights in what is their home. Accompanied by 32p. in-service training manual.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit

results.title: Up the Amazon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
The world’s greatest river, the Amazon, rises high in the Andes and flows for four thousand miles to the Atlantic Ocean. It is surrounded by the vast Amazon forest, which is seen by scientists as the world’s oxygen factory, and by Brazilians as a frontier to be conquered. The forest is being exploited and luxury hotels are being built throughout the hitherto impenetrable jungle. An interesting contrast between the “tourist” Amazon and the natural river and its surroundings. Narrated by Frank Windsor.

results.title: Crocodile
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, Christopher Parsons, Don Murray, British Broadcasting Corporation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A comprehensive treatment of saltwater and freshwater crocodiles. A ‘non-specialist’ film, it is nevertheless scientifically accurate, and takes a balanced view of this little understood and seldom loved reptile, which is now in danger of extinction. Narrated by Hugh Falkus. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: A Prospect of Kew
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
Richard Mabey goes beyond the showpiece attractions of the Kew Gardens in Surrey to reveal how its two centuries of history and its scientific research has made it the international centre for plant conservation.

results.title: Cross and passion
results.creator_credit: Claire Pollak, Kim Longinotto and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: The women of Northern Ireland tell their stories in this film shot in the troubled Catholic ghetto area of West Belfast. Shows how life for Women in Belfast’s ghettos is dominated by the contrasting power of the church and army.

results.title: One way ticket to Hualampong
results.creator_credit: Jeanne La Chard and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
Hualampong railway station is where thousands of children arrive hoping to find jobs but are sold into the misery and degradation of slavery and sin in Bangkok’s sweatshops, factories and brothels. Many simply disappear. The fact that children are an integral part of the work force is accepted in south east Asia, but in Thailand it is a cruel and thriving business.

results.title: Lawrence of Arabia didn't come down this far
results.creator_credit: Julian Cooper and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A carpenter from England in search of his personal dream worked on a building site in Kuwait for a year. Tells the story of his adventure, and also looks in detail at Kuwait and its secret, male dominated society. Photography by Ken Lowe and edited by Graham Shipham. Narrated by Jonathan Raban.
